description: From Middle English exil, borrowed from Old French essil, exil, from Latin exsilium, exilium (“state of exile”), derived from exsul, exul (“exiled person”).

entries.meaning: (uncountable) The state of being banished from one's home or country.
examples: They chose exile rather than assimilation.

entries.meaning: (countable) Someone who is banished from their home or country.

verbs.description: exile (third-person singular simple present exiles, present participle exiling, simple past and past participle exiled)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To send (someone or something) into exile.
